name: Independent Study: Honors
description: No more than 9 credits of Anthr 490 may be counted toward graduation.

name: Iowa Lakeside Laboratory
description: Research opportunities for undergraduate students in the biological sciences.   No more than 9 credits in Biol 490 may be counted toward graduation and of those, only 6 credits may be applied to the major.

name: Biological Anthropology and Archaeology
description: History of biological anthropology and archaeology, current developments and theoretical issues related to major events in human biocultural evolution and world prehistory.

name: Agroecosystems Analysis
description: Experiential, interdisciplinary examination of Midwestern agricultural and food systems, emphasizing field visits, with some classroom activities.  Focus on understanding multiple elements, perspectives (agronomic, economic, ecologic, social, etc.) and scales of operation.

name: Theoretical Dimensions of Cultural Anthropology
description: Survey of historical and current developments in topical and theoretical approaches to sociocultural anthropology. Examination and assessment of controversies; new research directions and theoretical approaches.

name: Applied Anthropology
description: Theoretical and practical considerations of applying anthropological knowledge to contemporary cultural, political and economic   issues. Dynamics of directed change in contemporary world cultures. Principles, theories, and ethics of international development   projects from a sociocultural perspective.

name: Kinship and Marriage  in a Global Perspective
description: Comparative and historical overview of the family, marriage and kinship. Examination of cross-cultural differences in the   construction and functioning of family and kin relations; role of kinship in structuring individual and collective activities; current   critical and theoretical issues in kinship studies, especially integrating work on gender and sexuality.

description: Field training experience in ethnography. Problems emphasizing field studies in the contemporary societies of the world. Focus on techniques of data gathering and analysis.

name: Current Issues in Native North America: Gender and Family
description: Exploration of key contemporary and historical issues in Native North America; discussion of current anthropological approaches to studying Native North America in a global context. Topics vary each time offered.   Only 9 credits of ANTHR/AM IN 332A, 332B, 332C, 332D may count toward graduation.

name: Current Issues in Native North America: Indigenous Ecologies and Geographies
description: Exploration of key contemporary and historical issues in Native North America; discussion of current anthropological approaches to studying Native North America in a global context.   Only 9 credits of ANTHR/AM IN 332A, 332B, 332C, 332D may count toward graduation.

name: Current Issues in Native North America: Cultural and Political Movements
description: Exploration of key contemporary and historical issues in Native North America; discussion of current anthropological approaches to studying Native North America in a global context. Topics vary each time offered.   Only 9 credits of ANTHR/AM IN 332A, 332B, 332C, 332D may count toward graduation.

name: Current Issues in Native North America: Regional Focus
description: Exploration of key contemporary and historical issues in Native North America; discussion of current anthropological approaches to studying Native North America in a global context. Topics vary each time offered.   Only 9 credits of ANTHR/AM IN 332A, 332B, 332C, 332D may count toward graduation.

name: Global Development
description: Cross-cultural analysis of current development practices from an anthropological perspective; focus on international aid,   development institutions, agrarian reform, indigenous knowledge, humanitarianism and human rights; introduction to main theories   of political and economic anthropology.

name: Primate Evolutionary Ecology and Behavior
description: Primate behavior and ecology in evolutionary perspective: biological and social adaptations of prosimians, monkeys, and apes. Introduction to the Order Primates, basic evolutionary concepts, and techniques of behavioral observation. Focus on theory and methods current in Primatology, including applied conservation biology.

name: Magic, Witchcraft, and Religion
description: Survey of global religious belief and practice from an anthropological perspective. Emphasis on myth and ritual, shamanism, magic,   witchcraft, beliefs in spirits, conceptions of the soul, mind and body relationships, and healing and therapeutic practices. Discussion   of religious response to dramatic political and social change; effects of globalization on religious practice.

name: Seminar in Forensic Sciences
description: Seminars by professional criminalists, research scientists, Certificate students, and educators. Emphasis on opportunities for   research and development, citizen involvement, and educational outreach related to forensic science. Weekly report required.

name: Independent Research and Presentation in Forensic Science
description: Research topic approved by course instructor. Written and oral reports required. Oral report given in forensics seminar, Chem 540.

name: Sex and Gender in Cross-cultural Perspective
description: Cross-cultural examination of the social construction of genders out of the biological fact of sex. Emphasis on non-western societies. Topics, presented through examination of ethnographic data, will include the range of gender variation, status and roles, the institution of marriage, and symbols of gender valuation.

name: Biological Field School
description: Summer field school for training in behavioral and ecological methods for primatologists. Proposal, data collection and analyses, and presentation of research topic in primatology.

name: Primate Behavior
description: An introduction to the Order Primates with a focus on their behavior.  Biological and social adaptations of monkeys, apes, and prosimians; basic evolutionary concepts, current trends and theories in the field of Primatology and issues related to primate conservation.

name: Topics in Biological Anthropology
description: In-depth study of current topics in biological anthropology, such as new fossil specimens, research on the evolution of cognition, the emergence of applied primatology, and the dynamic field of population genetics as each relates to the Order Primates.

name: Topics in Biological Anthropology: Paleoanthropology
description: In-depth study of current topics in biological anthropology, such as new fossil specimens, research on the evolution of cognition, the emergence of applied primatology, and the dynamic field of population genetics as each relates to the Order Primates.

name: Topics in Biological Anthropology: Primate Cognition
description: In-depth study of current topics in biological anthropology, such as new fossil specimens, research on the evolution of cognition, the emergence of applied primatology, and the dynamic field of population genetics as each relates to the Order Primates.

name: Topics in Biological Anthropology: Primate Conservation
description: In-depth study of current topics in biological anthropology, such as new fossil specimens, research on the evolution of cognition, the emergence of applied primatology, and the dynamic field of population genetics as each relates to the Order Primates.

name: Topics in Biological Anthropology: Population Genetics and Human Evolution
description: In-depth study of current topics in biological anthropology, such as new fossil specimens, research on the evolution of cognition, the emergence of applied primatology, and the dynamic field of population genetics as each relates to the Order Primates.

name: Orientation to Anthropology
description: Introduction to the Anthropology program, including the requirements for successful degree completion, department administrative procedures, ethics in anthropology and current trends in the four subfields of anthropology. Required of graduate students.   Offered on a satisfactory-fail basis only.

name: Foundations of Sustainable Agriculture
description: Historical, biophysical, socioeconomic, and ethical dimensions of agricultural sustainability. Strategies for evaluating existing and emerging agricultural systems in terms of the core concepts of sustainability and their theoretical contexts.

name: Orientation for AESHM
description: Orientation policies and procedures of university and college.  Guest speakers representing the university.  Some online lectures.

name: Professional Development for AESHM
description: Career exploration, presentation and professional skills, teamwork and leadership, creativity, critical thinking, technology, and service learning components.  Orientation to policies and procedures of college, department, and program.

name: Professional Development for AESHM:  Event Management and Hospitality Management
description: EVENT and HSP M career exploration, presentation and professional skills, teamwork and leadership, creativity, critical thinking, technology, and service learning components.  Orientation to policies and procedures of CHS college; AESHM department; and Event Management adn Hospitality Management programs.

name: Professional Development for AESHM:  Apparel, Merchandising, and Design
description: AMD career exploration, presentation and professional skills, teamwork and leadership, creativity, critical thinking, technology, and service learning components.  Orientation to policies and procedures of CHS college, AESHM department, and AMD program.

name: Supervised Work Experience I
description: Supervised work experience with a cooperating firm or organization.   No more than 12 credits total from AESHM 170, 270, and 470 may be applied toward graduation.

name: Supervised Work Experience I: Hospitality
description: Supervised work experience with a cooperating firm or organization.   No more than 12 credits total from AESHM 170, 270, and 470 may be applied toward graduation.

name: Supervised Work Experience I: Event Management
description: Supervised work experience with a cooperating firm or organization.   No more than 12 credits total from AESHM 170, 270, and 470 may be applied toward graduation.

name: Supervised Work Experience I: Apparel
description: Supervised work experience with a cooperating firm or organization.   No more than 12 credits total from AESHM 170, 270, and 470 may be applied toward graduation.

name: Supervised Work Experience I: ISU Dining
description: Supervised work experience with a cooperating firm or organization.   No more than 12 credits total from AESHM 170, 270, and 470 may be applied toward graduation.

name: Financial Applications for Retail and Hospitality Industries
description: Using an online delivery method, students will learn basic mathematical concepts, calculations and formulas commonly used in the apparel and hospitality industries. Emphasis on problem solving, critical/creative thinking, and mathematical interpretation of calculations and formulas used within the apparel and hospitality industries.

name: Financial Applications for Retail and Hospitality Industries: Hospitality Management
description: Using an online delivery method, students will learn basic mathematical concepts, calculations and formulas commonly used in the apparel and hospitality industries. Emphasis on problem solving, critical/creative thinking, and mathematical interpretation of calculations and formulas used within the hospitality industries.

name: Financial Applications for Retail and Hospitality Industries: Retail Merchandising
description: Using an online delivery method, students will learn basic mathematical concepts, calculations and formulas commonly used in the apparel and hospitality industries. Emphasis on problem solving, critical/creative thinking, and mathematical interpretation of calculations and formulas used within the apparel industries.

name: Leadership Experiences and Development (LEAD)
description: Introduction to leadership behaviors.  Development and utilization of leadership behaviors to positively impact school life, community life, and work life.

name: Creative Thinking and Problem Solving
description: Focus on creative thinking concepts, strategies, and methods.  Systematic application of creative thinking techniques to:  view things from different perspectives; identify unique opportunities; solve problems; generate and evaluate original ideas.  Field trips might be required.

name: Supervised Work Experience II
description: Supervised work experience with a cooperating firm or organization.   No more than 12 credits total from AESHM 170, 270, and 470 may be applied toward graduation.

name: Supervised Work Experience II: Hospitality
description: Supervised work experience with a cooperating firm or organization.   No more than 12 credits total from AESHM 170, AESHM 270, and 470 may be applied toward graduation.

name: Supervised Work Experience II: Event Management
description: Supervised work experience with a cooperating firm or organization.   No more than 12 credits total from AESHM 170, 270, and 470 may be applied toward graduation.

name: Supervised Work Experience II: Apparel
description: Supervised work experience with a cooperating firm or organization.   No more than 12 credits total from AESHM 170, 270, and 470 may be applied toward graduation.

name: Supervised Work Experience II: ISU Dining
description: Supervised work experience with a cooperating firm or organization.   No more than 12 credits total from AESHM 170, 270, and 470 may be applied toward graduation.

name: Fashion Show Production and Promotion
description: Planning and production of fashion show including developing budgets, public relations, advertising, fund-raising, choreography, staging, lighting, and food.  Promotion of fashion show and similar events.   Maximum of 4 credits can be applied to graduation

name: Orientation to U.S. Field Study
description: Orientation to the field study location during the semester preceding the trip.

name: Orientation to International Field Study
description: Orientation to the field study location during the semester preceding the trip.

name: Principles of Management in Human Sciences
description: Introduction to management concepts and principles with application to human sciences-related businesses and organizations. Includes service quality management, professionalism, and social responsibility.

name: Seminar on Careers and Internships
description: Internship and career planning, professional expectations and responsibilities. RÌÄå©sumÌÄå© development, cover letters, interviewing techniques, and business etiquette.

name: Seminar on Careers and Internships:  Event Management and Hospitality Management
description: Internship and career planning, professional expectations and responsibilities.  RÌÄå©sumÌÄå© development, cover letters, interviewing techniques, and business etiquette.

name: Seminar on Careers and Internships:  Apparel, Merchandising, and Design
description: Internship and career planning, professional expectations and responsibilities. RÌÄå©sumÌÄå© development, cover letters, interviewing techniques, and business etiquette.

name: Hospitality and Apparel Marketing Strategies
description: Application of marketing principles to the hospitality-, events-, and apparel-related industries.  Emphasis on the role of marketing in an organization's overall strategic planning.  Development and evaluation techniques available to hospitality, events, apparel, and related businesses, including advertising, sales promotion, packaging, and public relations.

name: Aesthetics of Consumer Experience
description: Design principles, aesthetic concepts, and research applied to consumer experiences, with an emphasis on hospitality and retail environments and events.  Influence of individual differences and cultural patterns on aesthetic preferences.

name: Community Leadership:  Examination of Social Issues
description: Study of family and community social issues from diverse perspectives. Application of critical thinking and reflection to issues with a focus on leadership within the community.

name: U.S. Field Study
description: Study and tours of areas of interest to majors in the AESHM Department. Trip to location under supervision of faculty member. Locations and lengths of trip vary. Final projects, reports, journal entries, and analysis are required.

name: U.S. Field Study:  Hospitality Management
description: Study and tours of areas of interest to majors in the Hospitality Management program.  Trip to location under supervision of faculty member. Locations and lengths of trip vary. Final projects, reports, journal entries, and analysis are required.

description: Study and tours of areas of interest to majors in the majors in the Event Management program.  Trip to location under supervision of faculty member. Locations and lengths of trip vary. Final projects, reports, journal entries, and analysis are required.

description: Study and tours of areas of interest to majors in the Apparel, Merchandising, and Design major.  Trip to location under supervision of faculty member. Locations and lengths of trip vary. Final projects, reports, journal entries, and analysis are required.

name: Cooperative Education
description: Required of all cooperative education students seeking full-time status. Students register for this course prior to commencing each work period.

name: Seminar on Current Issues
description: Trends, issues, and scholarship in apparel, events, and hospitality management.

name: Seminar on Current Issues: Events and Hospitality
description: Trends, issues, and scholarship in events and hospitality management.

name: Seminar on Current Issues: Apparel
description: Trends, issues, and scholarship in apparel.

name: Developing Global Leadership:  Maximizing Human Potential
description: Development of leadership in a global environment.  Focus on global concerns that impact on the well-being of individuals, families, and communities.  Strategies for working with individuals, families and communities in other countries and cultures.  Taking local action on global issues.  Participation in a service activity.

name: Human Resource Management
description: Principles and practices of human resource management relevant to human science-related organizations.  Emphasis on the entry-level manager's role.

name: Supervised Professional Internship
description: Supervised work experience with a cooperating firm or organization.

name: Supervised Professional Internship: Hospitality
description: Supervised work experience with a cooperating firm or organization.   No more than 12 credits from AESHM 170, 270, and 470 may be applied toward graduation.

description: Supervised work experience with a cooperating firm or organization.   No more than 12 credits from AESHM 170, 270, and 470 may be applied toward graduation.

name: Supervised Professional Internship: ISU Dining
description: Supervised work experience with a cooperating firm or organization.   No more than 12 credits from AESHM 170, 270, and 470 may be applied toward graduation.

name: Fashion Show Management
description: Provide leadership and communicate direction for planning and production of fashion show, including developing budgets, publicity, advertising, fundraising, choreography, staging, lighting, and food.

name: Entrepreneurship in Human Sciences
description: Comprehensive approach to entrepreneurship including concepts of innovation, creativity, opportunity assessment, and business planning.  Focus on human sciences-related businesses: retail, service, hospitality, event, food-related, family-owned, rural, and community businesses. Interaction with entrepreneurs, market research, feasibility analysis, business proposals, and business/community outreach and consulting.

name: Research Methods in Apparel and Hospitality
description: Overview of research methods. Methods for collecting and analyzing quantitative and qualitative data. Development of research plan.

name: Seminar
description: Discussion of scholarship and current issues. Topics vary.

name: Practicum
description: Supervised experience related to career objective. Proposal must be approved semester before placement.

Focus on human sciences-related businesses: retail, service, hospitality, event, food-related, family-owned, rural, and community businesses. Interaction with entrepreneurs, market research, feasibility analysis, business proposals, and business/community outreach and consulting.

description: Study and tours of areas of interest to majors in the AESHM Department. Trip to location under supervision of faculty member. Locations and lengths of trip vary. Final projects, reports, journal entries, and analysis are required.

description: Study and tours of areas of interest to majors in the Apparel, Merchandising, and Design. Trip to location under supervision of faculty member. Locations and lengths of trip vary. Final projects, reports, journal entries, and analysis are required.

name: Seminar
description: Scholarship and current issues. Topics vary.

name: Teaching Practicum
description: Supervised experience in the university classroom. Proposal must be approved semester before placement.

name: Teaching Practicum:  Apparel Merchandising and Design
description: Supervised experience in the university classroom. Proposal must be approved semester before placement.

name: Teaching Practicum:  Hospitality Management
description: Supervised experience in the university classroom. Proposal must be approved semester before placement.

name: Apparel Construction Techniques
description: Assemble components and completed garments with the use of basic sewing equipment. Learn basic construction techniques, applications and vocabulary. Students will need access to a home sewing machine, iron, computer and the internet. Not available for credit for A M D majors.

name: Apparel Assembly Processes
description: Principles of garment assembly. Use of mass production equipment and methods to analyze, develop and assemble garments.

name: Overview of the Fashion Industry
description: Introduction to fashion industry, industry structure from concept to consumer.  Focus on fashion-driven consumer goods.

name: Dress and Diversity in Society
description: Examination of diversity among consumers and introduction to forecasting trends in dress.  Introduction to social justice issues.

name: Introduction to Apparel Design Studio
description: Introduction to the elements and principles of design in fashion and apparel including skill development in fashion illustration, technical drawing, and fabric rendering using traditional media.  Application of written and verbal presentations to communicate fashion and apparel design concepts.  Fashion presentation and introduction to portfolio development.

name: Textile Science
description: Textile fibers, yarns, fabrication, coloration, and finishes.  Quality and performance application to consumer soft goods and technical textiles.  Online components and lab work.

name: Design Selective Advancement
description: Project review and skill assessment related to 2-dimensional and 3-dimensional visualization, apparel assembly, basic product knowledge, design problem solving, illustration, textiles.   Offered on a satisfactory-fail basis only.  Only one credit in 206 may be counted towards graduation.

name: Computer Applications in Digital Design and Data Management
description: Applications of basic skills in Photoshop, Illustrator, PLM-type software, Excel, and databases.  Introduction to digital product design and line development.  Focus on elements and principles of design.  Introduction to digital portfolio development for design and merchandising.  Online lectures.

name: Patternmaking I:  Drafting and Flat Pattern
description: Application of patternmaking tools and their functions, measurement techniques, pattern labeling, and patternmaking communication documents.  Sloper drafting and flat pattern manipulation methods for women's apparel.  Design and construction of original garments using drafted slopers and flat pattern manipulation methods to enable the analysis of fit.

name: Product Development and Manufacturing
description: Analysis of apparel product development, sourcing, and manufacturing processes.  Focus on materials and specifications relative to quality, performance, cost, and price.  Applications of software for PLM.

name: Aesthetics and Brand Image
description: Elements and principles of design. Analysis of sensory, expressive, and symbolic aspects that build brand image, with a focus on fashion products and promotional settings.

name: Museum Studies
description: Overview of museums including history, functions, and philosophy.  Collection and curatorial practices.  Funding and governance issues.  Hands-on object research and exhibit development.  Required field trip.

name: Retail Merchandising
description: Principles of merchandising as applied to retail-, service-, events-, and hospitality-related businesses.  Study of the planning, development, and presentation of apparel- and hospitality-related products, services, and experiences.  Industry and market research, planning of new offerings, and development of promotional and competitive strategies for various retail formats.

name: Fashion Illustration
description: Development of fashion plates and focused apparel lines/collections.  Proficiency in drawing the fashion figure, technical drawings/flats, and apparel using a variety of media.  Continuation of fashion presentation and portfolio development.

name: Quality Assurance of Textiles and Apparel
description: Principles of product and materials evaluation and quality assurance. Developing specifications and using standard practices for evaluating materials, product characteristics, performance, and quality.

name: Computer Integrated Textile and Fashion Design
description: Computer-aided design technology used in apparel sketching, pattern drafting, grading, and marker making.

name: Computer Integrated Textile and Fashion Design
description: Analysis and advanced use of computer-aided design software for textile and fashion design for various target markets.  Digital presentation and portfolio development.

name: Patternmaking II:  Draping
description: Principles of patternmaking through basic draping techniques on industry standard body forms.  Apparel design through analysis of fit and design; problem solving and interaction of fabric characteristics with style features.

name: Design Seminar
description: Focus on artisanal textile, apparel, or surface and structural design techniques.  Design processes for specialty fabrics and markets.  Topics vary by term.

name: History of European and North American Dress
description: Survey of history of dress from ancient times up to the American Civil War; focus on European and North American dress. Emphasis on connection of dress to the social, cultural, environmental, and technological contexts of the Western world.

name: History of Twentieth Century Fashion
description: Survey of major design and technological developments from the American Civil War through the 20th Century. Emphasis on fashion as a system of design and production, culture of consumption, fashion change, and trends in art, society, and culture.

name: Cultural Perspectives of Dress
description: Analysis of multiple factors related to dress in selected societies, including technology, cultural identity, aesthetics, social organization, ritual, stability and change. Applications to fair trade and social responsibility.

name: Sourcing and Global Issues
description: Evaluation of key issues facing textile and apparel industries in global markets considering ethical, economic, political, social, and professional implications.  Sourcing strategies in a global environment.  Corporate and consumer social responsibility and sustainability.

name: Merchandise Planning and Control
description: Calculations and computer application in the planning and control of merchandise.  Emphasis on retail math as it pertains to assortment planning, the six-month buying plan process, and other buying concepts and strategies.  Online modules.

name: Brand Management and Promotions
description: Principles of brand development and management; emphasis on branding, visual merchandising, design/layout of retail spaces.  Includes merchandising technology applications such as Adobe Creative Suite and retail-related case studies.

name: Advanced Textile Science
description: Theories and principles of textile science.  Emphasis on fiber structure on fabric properties and performance; new developments in textiles.

name: Technical Design Processes
description: Garment development and analysis of fit, performance, quality, cost. Exploration of alternative materials, construction methods, grading; specifications and portfolio development.

name: Creative Design Processes
description: Exploration of the creative process and sources of inspiration with emphasis on wearable art; experimentation of advanced design problem solving, alternative materials, fabric manipulation, and pattern-making techniques.

name: Apparel Production Management
description: Procedures and experiences related to application and use of process controls: method analysis, work measurement, costing, pricing, and production planning. Resource management, technology applications, and quality assurance.

name: Textile Conservation and Collection Management
description: Condition assessment, repair, and stabilization of textiles and apparel in museum collections.  Dry and aqueous cleaning.  Examination of storage and exhibition techniques, materials, and conditions.  Experience with cataloging and management practices.

name: Consumer Behavior
description: Application of concepts and theories from the social sciences to the study of consumer behavior related to dress, textile and apparel products, and retail experiences. Experience in conducting consumer research.

name: Retail Information Analysis
description: Evaluation of information needed to make effective retail decisions.  Use of technology in analyzing and interpreting retail systems data.  Application of concepts related to forecasting, consumer demand, assortment planning, market research, data mining, database interface, pattern recognition, supply-chain/logistics management, retail technology applications such as Visual Retailing, PLM, and Sourcing Simulator.

name: Multi-channel Retailing
description: A customer-centric view of marketing with a focus on the retailer-customer relationship and online strategies.  Integration of key characteristics of online and offline marketing including store formats, e-commerce, catalog, TV, mobile, and direct sales.

name: Independent Study
description: Independent Study.

name: Independent Study: History of Dress and Textiles
Independent Study: Textile and Apparel Design
Independent Study: Sociological and Psychological Aspects of Dress and Textiles
Senior Design Studio
description: Creation of an apparel line from target market research to prototypes through the use of manual techniques and CAD technologies.  The line is to be included in a professional portfolio and pieces submitted to a juried exhibition.

name: Fashion Forecasting and Product Development
description: Applying consumer, aesthetic, and quantitative trend information to develop value-added apparel/textile products and product lines with merchandising/promotion campaigns for diverse target markets. Multi-function team projects. Presentation to industry representatives.

name: Undergraduate Research
description: Research experience in textiles and clothing with application to a selected problem.

name: Advanced Textile Science
description: Theories and principles of textile science.  Emphasis on fiber structure on fabric properties and performance; new developments in textiles.

name: Quality Assurance of Textiles and Apparel
description: Principles of product and materials evaluation and quality assurance. Developing specifications and using standard practices for evaluating materials, product characteristics, performance, and quality. Proposal and research project.

name: Foundation of Scholarship in Textiles and Clothing
description: Overview of scholarship in textiles and clothing with emphasis on current and future directions.  Fundamentals of writing literature reviews.  Examination of ethical issues in scholarship and academic life.  Introduction to creativity, sustainability, and entrepreneurship.  Development of teaching units.

name: Digital Technologies in Textile and Apparel Design
description: Digital technologies in textile and apparel design. Theories and practices of mass customization and personalization, digital textile printing, 3D body scanning, creating avatars from body scans, and fitting digital apparel designs.

name: Creative Design Processes
description: Exploration of the creative process and sources of inspiration with emphasis on wearable art; experimentation of advanced design problem solving, alternative materials, fabric manipulation, and pattern-making techniques.

name: Design Seminar
description: Focus on artisanal textile, apparel, or surface and structural design techniques.  Design processes for specialty fabrics and markets.  Topics vary by term.

name: Consumer Aesthetics and Retail Branding
description: Examination of hedonic nature of consumer experience and its application to experiential design and branding of retail/hospitality establishments. Emphasis on consumer behavior, environmental psychology, and marketing literature.

name: Textile Conservation and Collection Management
description: Condition assessment, repair, and stabilization of textiles and apparel in museum collections.  Dry and aqueous cleaning.  Examination of storage and exhibition techniques, materials, and conditions.  Experience with cataloging and management practices.

name: Sustainability:  Theory and Practical Application
description: Overview of current sustainability theory, research, and methodology.  Emphasis on the evaluation and discussion of current sustainability literature and sustainable practice of apparel, textiles, and related products and services through people, processes, and the environment.  Development and presentation of original scholarly and creative design work under various sustainability frameworks.

name: Consumer Behavior and Apparel
description: Application of concepts and theories from the social sciences to the study of consumer behavior. Experience in conducting research; manuscript writing.

name: Sourcing and Global Issues
description: Evaluation of textile and apparel industries in global markets considering ethical, economic, political, social, and professional implications. Sourcing strategies in a global environment.  Corporate and consumer social responsibility and sustainability.  Experience in conducting research using secondary data.

name: Industry Applications in Merchandising and Management
description: Using the case study method, students apply merchandising theory, principles, and practices to industry scenarios.  Emphasis on problem solving, creative thinking, data analysis, and data interpretation involved in business operations.  Focus on the development of leadership skills while functioning in small and large groups.

name: E-Commerce for Apparel and Hospitality Companies
description: Analysis of technology and consumer trends, industry practices, and marketing strategies for e-commerce.  Evaluation and development of apparel or hospitality company websites.  Theory application to the development of multi-channel business strategies.

name: Special Topics
description: Individually designed textile and clothing-related projects that reflect the special interests of the student.

name: Special Topics: Textile Science
description: Individually designed textile and clothing-related projects that reflect the special interests of the student.

name: Special Topics: History of Dress and Textiles
description: Individually designed textile and clothing-related projects that reflect the special interests of the student.

name: Special Topics: Textile and Apparel Design
description: Individually designed textile and clothing-related projects that reflect the special interests of the student.

description: Individually designed textile and clothing-related projects that reflect the special interests of the student.

description: Individually designed textile and clothing-related projects that reflect the special interests of the student.
